title: Are potential differences zero or not

content.description: The figure above shows Resistor <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>R</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and an initially uncharged capacitor connected in a circuit with a switch and a battery.
content.question: A long time after the switch is closed, the potential differences across the battery, the resistor, and the capacitor are constant. Which of the following correctly indicates whether the potential differences are zero or nonzero?

choices.label: The potential difference across the battery is zero, the potential difference across the resistor is nonzero, and the potential difference across the capacitor is nonzero.
The potential difference across the battery is nonzero, the potential difference across the resistor is zero, and the potential difference across the capacitor is zero.
The potential difference across the battery is nonzero, the potential difference across the resistor is zero, and the potential difference across the capacitor is nonzero.
The potential difference across the battery is nonzero, the potential difference across the resistor is nonzero, and the potential difference across the capacitor is zero.

content.answer: The potential difference across the battery is nonzero, the potential difference across the resistor is zero, and the potential difference across the capacitor is nonzero.
